slides.title: Introduction to Environmental Performance
content: Organizations increasingly prioritize environmental protection, showcasing products and services as eco-friendly.
Stringent environmental legislations, policies, and growing public awareness drive this focus on environmental commitment.
Traditional pollution control relied on enforced standards, but internal objectives and goals are increasingly preferred.
Environmental Quality Objectives (EQOs) allow organizations to showcase their environmental performance for transparency.
slides.script: Welcome to the introduction of Environmental Performance Standards! This section will highlight how companies are going beyond simply following environmental regulations to demonstrate a genuine commitment to sustainability. We will focus on environmental quality standards and their role to improve organizational environmental policy

slides.title: Environmental Quality Objectives (EQOs) Defined
content: EQOs are generally non-enforceable goals targeting specific environmental quality levels in specific area.
Unlike environmental quality standards, EQOs typically lack quantification and are not legally enforceable.
Government bodies are framing goals and objectives in terms of EQOs to create a transparent, reliable outline.
These objectives guide effort on different levels, from individuals to state-wide governmental projects.
slides.script: This slide will help us define what exactly Environmental Quality Objectives are. These aims, or goals, are meant to be followed not by legal obligation but by good intentions. Also EQOs lack quantification and are not legally enforceable

slides.title: Typical EQOs for Governing Body
content: Reduce climate impact due to widespread pollution, ensuring minimal contribution to global warming problems.
Maintaining clean air quality, minimizing harmful emissions for improved respiratory health and reduced smog.
Reduce Acid Rain in the nation, protecting lakes and landscapes from hazardous acidification.
Actively protect and restore the ozone layer, minimizing harmful radiation from the sun. Also reduce eutrofication.
Pollution-free bodies of water (Surface, Ground and Marine), by decreasing effluent discharge to water systems.
Seeking development of forest sector and agriculture.
Seeking nuclear radiation levels as low as reasonably achievable
slides.script: Now we move onto the typical EQOs from a Governmental standpoint. These are general environmental goals that serve as an index for evaluating the environmental performance of the whole nation

slides.title: ISO 14000: Environmental Management System (EMS)
content: ISO 14000 series standards encourage effective, efficient environmental management within organizations.
These standards offer tools for continual improvements in environmental performance, promoting sustainable practices.
Critical areas involve environmental policy framing and setting measurable, achievable objectives and targets.
They can also provide guidance for organizations to reduce greenhouse emissions and improve environmental footprint.
slides.script: The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) based at Geneva, Switzerland are involved with developing Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and are voluntary in nature. This slide will help us cover those aspects.

slides.title: Key Components of ISO 14000 Implementation
content: Securing management's commitment is crucial, demonstrating leadership and environmental responsibility throughout organization.
Conducting a preliminary review and audit establishes baseline environmental status.
Framing a comprehensive environmental policy that aligns with the organization’s broader objectives.
Clearly defined organization structure and allocated resources, ensuring that each department can meet their goals.
Setting objectives and targets with continuous monitoring and review programs can help improve organizational environmental performance.
slides.script: These are some essential ingredients for ensuring that an EMS project goes without a hitch. Management support, baseline review, resource allocation, and target setting are essential. Please ask me if you have any questions.

slides.title: Quantifiable Measures for Environmental Performance
content: Measuring yield on product (Output/Input) as it demonstrates efficiency in production and reduction of waste.
Monitoring waste/emission generation (kgs of Waste/kgs of Product) is essential in minimizing waste and pollution.
Track energy consumption (KWH/Kg of Product) as efficient power use can reduce energy consumption.
Water consumption monitoring (Cu.M/Kg of Product), ensuring efficient utilization of water resources, is important.
Compliance with effluent discharge standards (Quantity and Concentration) to regulate pollution.
slides.script: On this slide, we will cover some quantifiable parameters. We will be measuring how much of a product/energy are being utilized and we will measure the waste emitted per unit of product produced

slides.title: Developmental Policy’s Core Features
content: Developmental Policy decides what an organization is planning to do in the future.
A good Development policy must identify clear objectives and the tools to achieve them effectively.
A plan of action needs to be mapped out and carefully followed.
Must set principles and directives that guide the decisions of the organization.
A Developmental policy must ensure Reduced pollution levels as well as preserve natural resources.
slides.script: Let us cover what defines developmental policy. In the environmental context, the government ensures the platform to implement sustainable management practices. The goals in a developmental policy should also align with the objectives of NGOs.

slides.title: The Environmental Developmental Policy Cycle
content: First, the environmental problems must be identified with widespread public debate and consensus.
Next, proposals need to be put together for approval.
After approval, policies can be implemented under governmental supervision to ensure accountability.
Next step involves assessment of results and impacts.
slides.script: Policies have an evolution cycle. A good developmental policy needs to pass though all of these stages and be iterative in order to be successful.

slides.title: Agenda for Action and Sustainable Development
content: Use resources equitably to meet basic needs, present and future, without environmental harm.
Ensure control and prevention of future deterioration in land, water, and air quality.
Locate projects carefully to minimize adverse environmental consequences.
Conserve biological diversity and the gene pool, protecting endangered species, and reducing eutrofication.
slides.script: For sustainable development to be possible, it is important to remember certain action points. It is important to provide equitable resources to the people while preventing environmental decay and also to conserve our biodiversity.

slides.title: Essential Instruments for Environmental Action
content: Integrate environmental assessments into project planning, linking them to economic factors for balanced decisions.
Implement clear prior environmental clearance protocols for projects in ecologically sensitive locations.
Prioritize research, development, and adoption of environmentally compatible technologies, moving beyond fossil fuels.
Increase individual and collective awareness through mass-contact programmes.
slides.script: Here, we outline some of the instruments to support environmental action. Impact assessments and proper policies go a long way in improving the environment. Please ask me if you have questions about any of this.

slides.title: Policy Actions: Population Control and Conservation
content: Controlling population growth reduces the demand for resources and lowers environmental stress.
Implement measures such as education and health care to incentivize family planning.
For conservation of water, strict measures on industry, agriculture and house-hold wastage are needed.
Incentivize green tech and provide better renewable energy to all sectors.
slides.script: This slide will go into detail about the policy action that should be undertaken. Incentives and punitive measures, clean technologies are to be implemented. Any questions?

slides.title: Key Actions for Development Sectors
content: Prioritize soil quality through sustainable farming and minimal chemical usage.
Implement efficient irrigation systems to conserve water resources.
Adopt eco-friendly technologies and prioritize waste utilization in all types of industries, especially for hazardous substances.
Implement tourism while causing minimal environmental damage and regulations of tourist activities in sensible areas.
slides.script: More policy actions from key development sectors for balancing development and environmental safety. In summary, the policies will vary depending on the sector, however all should lead to sustainable development. Any questions?

slides.title: Economic Instruments for Environmental Policy
content: Economic instruments use market mechanisms to affect environmental outcomes by altering costs and benefits.
Aim to influence through pricing, making environmentally preferable actions financially attractive.
Instrument types: taxes, charges, subsidies, and deposit-refund systems are often used to alter pricing.
They can be difficult to design effectively due to some people's resistance to new taxes.
slides.script: Now, for some economic instruments. These are a market mechanism that improve the state of the environment by influencing costs and benefits to create greater opportunity.

slides.title: Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)
content: NGOs represent citizen groups, expert panels, or industry coalitions advocating for environmental protection.
They often engage in grassroots activities or provide unbiased expert advice.
NGOs help implement governmental policies and raise awareness.
The NGOs often advocate for action on problems and create effective solutions.
slides.script: Now we cover NGOs. They don't represent governments and they focus their effort on either providing help or expertise. Here are the highlights from the slide.

slides.title: International Cooperation and Agreements
content: Addressing global environmental challenges requires international collaboration and consensus.
The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) helps frame various International Convention.
Agreements such as CITES safeguard wildlife threatened by international trade, reducing greenhouse emissions.
Many nations are bound to implement their own national laws so that CITES and agreements are followed.
slides.script: For this last slide, we wrap up by discussing that global environmental issues can only be fixed by coming to an agreement with international parties. The UN oversees these discussions and their role in environmental sustainability. That's all for this chapter, thank you for watching!
